80 years later, the memories of these men, and all those impacted in the attack on Pearl Harbor, lives on. And it’s Rep. Gallagher's hope that as we reflect on these stories of service and sacrifice, we’re all inspired to conduct ourselves in a way that’s worthy of their service.

Joseph Muhofski; Radioman 3rd Class; Navy; USS Pennsylvania.
 
Mr. Muhofski was born and raised in Kewaunee, where he is laid to rest with his parents, Joseph and Lucy, at Holy Rosary Cemetery.

Earl Wallen; Private 1st Class; Marine Corps; USS California.

Mr. Wallen of Pensaukee attended St. Norbert College for a year before enlisting. For his heroic actions St. Norbert granted him an honorary degree and American Legion Post 11 in Green Bay bears his name.

Laxton Newman; Aviation Machinist’s Mate 3rd Class; Navy; Kaneohe NAS.
 
Mr. Newman was from Crivitz. He was awarded a Silver Star Medal for his service and later had a Buckley-class destroyer escort named after him, the USS Newman.

Herbert McLaughlin; Private; Army; Hickman Field.
 
Mr. Mclaughln was from Shawano. The VFW in Shawano is currently named after him. He is tragically still missing in action but is honored at Honolulu Memorial in Hawaii.

Philip Gazecki, Ensign; Navy (reserve); USS Arizona.
 
Mr. Gazecki attended Menasha High, where he was the salutatorian of his class. He later attended Harvard and developed a paint that was used to keep barnacles from attaching to ships in World War II.

Malachy Cashen; Corporal; Army; Wheeler Field.
 
Mr. Cashen attended School in Outagamie County while in the service, and was laid to rest in the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific in Hawaii.

William Bruesewitz, Seaman 1st Class; Navy USS Oklahoma.
 
Mr. Bruesewitz was born in Clinton and lived in Appleton while serving. His body was not identified until 2018, and he was eventually laid to rest in Arlington National Cemetery on the 77th anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

President Biden is blowing through norms with the sheer volume and scope of these executive orders. That's wrong. But it shouldn't be surprising. The next president, regardless of party, will probably do the same thing.

So what happens when Congress decides not to play its part? First, the other branches step in to fill the space. Courts legislate from the bench. The president and bureaucracy tackle problems and policy however they like.

In the short term, this behavior wins the praise of partisans. But in the longer term it creates instability and chaos in our constitutional system. Every single election, the disposition of the entire federal government changes on a dime, across a wide range of issues.

That hurts the economy, it sows confusion among citizens, and it often helps the powerful and the connected at the expense of everybody else. That, in turn, raises the stakes for each election - because seemingly everything turns on the outcome.

Put simply: Congress. Every president issues guidance to the executive branch. That's normal. But when Congress passes bad, vague, or imprecise laws, it opens up space that executive orders fill. In other words, Congress enables presidential discretion.

Our constitution is designed to have Congress at the center. We are supposed to be making laws and directing the government. The president and the federal courts are empowered to check Congress, but they are not supposed to replace our legislative authority.

This is THE biggest problem with Congress today. You may have heard that America has three coequal branches. This is wrong. Congress is the dominant branch of government. We are the first branch, and we have the most power over the other two.
This is 100% right. We are not acting aggressively enough. We need a targeted travel ban immediately or this will get much worse and we will see human-to-human transmission in the US.

Why do we have a Congress?

Presumably we have a Congress to deliberate, debate, and legislate. When it comes to border security, Congress has done none of these things.
